miniProfile.occupation: Product Manager at Rete.ai | TIKAJ | Cyber Security Consultant
Product Manager at Rete.ai | TIKAJ | Cyber Security Consultant

text.text:
(Engineering#3): We are at 1.2TB/~250k products at $30 per month in Blinkstore. "So how we managing the infrastructure ?"

First things first. Stats 
1. 1.2TB/mo  (805GB from *. blinkstore(.)in &  ~450GB from custom domains)
2. 10k+ creators & 250k products with 300GB of Images. 

Costs approximately - $30/mo. Below is breakdown:
1. 0 cost in Cloudflare (They are just super generous) 
2. $6 for Azure Bandwidth & 10$ for server. Right now we are paying nothing.  Thanks to Microsoft for Startups
3. $7 for Storage 
5. $0.12 for Emails. (AWS SES for Emails)

Let's talk about managing infrastructure. We will cover each segment element by element. 
0. Domain : We use HashiCorp Terraform IaC to manage all configurations. It ensures that we don't messup config and code review based approach ensures we don't misconfigure things. From security perspective - no one is allowed to modify the settings directly. 

Everything is extremely cached, and we use Cloudflare caching rules to force Edge Caching, which extends the lifetime of our objects. This significantly reduces cost.

1.  Server : We are not willing to pay a lot of cost per server - which brings in presumption that no server is going to last forever. It's best for DR and other reasons. 

We treat all servers as stateless. Exception of database.
This is nothing new people using micro services do that - it's just you need to have this thought process even if you aren't. 

All servers etc are provisioned though Terraform, & configured using ansible. It barely takes 10min to add new server to cluster in any cloud (almost). 

2. Orchestration : Deployments. The delima with orchestration is you get good orchestration & management with Kubernetes but it's heavy - it will cost a lot.  
Manual deployments are pain - avoid deploying manually through ssh. It's never going to scale. 

We selected Nomad. It's a rock solid product - you can start with just one node & scale to hundreds. (We have tested it.) Memory foot print is almost 0. 

Use Podman instead of Docker for small VM.

---
We have domain, servers provisioned and orchestration in place - but how to pay nothing ? 

4. Free/Cheap Servers : Since you infrastructure is stateless you can easily add few nomad server without pain and remove them without much impact. Eg: you can get few free server in cloud with 1gb etc or you can even get cheap servers there are always offers. Digital ocean, Linode etc . 

The whole point of having a free server approach is to avoid any cloud lock-ins. (There are lot of cheap resources like Spot Instances, I can cover later)

5. Multi-Cloud : Alright, Next thing is all these servers are not going to be one network. Though this is not recommended but use P2P Mesh VPN to get all these serves in one network. Eg: Nebula by Slack, ZeroTier, Inc. or Tailscale. 

The best part is you can connect your machine for AI/ML stuff if need be.

This is more about approach than process. 

#engineering #architecture #infrastructure #cloud

text.text:
As an occasional hiring manager at TIKAJ, I have had the opportunity to go through quite a few job applications.

Only today did I realize something about how I skim the applications (how it is mostly done), and despite the number of applications, why most don't stand out.

I decided to share my very basic observations across, in case our next hire finds this useful :)

Resume filtering starts in the order below:

1. First thing that is read, even before your name or skills - Cover letter/ Introductory statement in your resume. 𝗕𝗮𝗱 𝗴𝗿𝗮𝗺𝗺𝗮𝗿, 𝗺𝗶𝘀𝘀𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗽𝘂𝗻𝗰𝘁𝘂𝗮𝘁𝗶𝗼𝗻, 𝗻𝗼𝘁 𝗰𝗮𝗽𝗶𝘁𝗮𝗹𝗶𝘇𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝘀𝗲𝗻𝘁𝗲𝗻𝗰𝗲𝘀 - the very first filter, within 3 seconds.
2. COVER LETTER IN ALL CAPS. It hurts.
3. Attaching resume in 𝗪𝗼𝗿𝗱 𝗳𝗼𝗿𝗺𝗮𝘁 𝗿𝗮𝘁𝗵𝗲𝗿 𝘁𝗵𝗮𝗻 𝗣𝗗𝗙 - PDF preserves formatting on all platforms, and ensures that the document looks exactly the way you intended. (this might hurt in the case of larger companies using ATS, so decide accordingly).
3. 𝗡𝗼𝘁 𝗵𝗶𝗴𝗵𝗹𝗶𝗴𝗵𝘁𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗿𝗲𝗹𝗲𝘃𝗮𝗻𝘁 𝘀𝗸𝗶𝗹𝗹𝘀 - nobody will know unless you explicitly tell.
4. 𝗡𝗼𝘁 𝘀𝗵𝗼𝘄𝗰𝗮𝘀𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗮 𝗿𝗲𝗹𝗲𝘃𝗮𝗻𝘁 𝗽𝗼𝗿𝘁𝗳𝗼𝗹𝗶𝗼 or work background. 
5. Writing too little or too much - keep it concise.

Additional tips:

1. It would save a lot of time for the recruiter if you will 𝘀𝗮𝘃𝗲 𝘆𝗼𝘂𝗿 𝗿𝗲𝘀𝘂𝗺𝗲 𝘄𝗶𝘁𝗵 𝗮𝗻 𝗶𝗱𝗲𝗻𝘁𝗶𝗳𝗶𝗮𝗯𝗹𝗲 𝗻𝗮𝗺𝗲 𝗳𝗼𝗿𝗺𝗮𝘁. E.g.: FirstName_LastName_TargetRole.pdf, rather than Resume2022.pdf
2. A little security tip - do not include your postal address or any other personal information which is irrelevant to the position. 

I appreciate and respect the time every applicant puts in reading the JD and applying. A little bit of effort can make the required difference! 🚀

#resumetips #hiring #opportunity #fresher #talentacquisition

miniProfile.occupation: Co-founder, Blinkstore | Into Product, Marketing, & SEO
Building Blinkstore and experimenting at XYZ Studio

text.text:
(Engineering#2): How we are handling with 4000+ stores in Blinkstore at cost of approximately ~5$ per month on infrastructure ?

Use everything that's there for free. I won't talk about how we manage the infrastructure. 

0. I started designing the architecture  with one thought - Blinkstore should survive the promise of free forever. Only way to achieve it is by staying poor. 
 
1. We used MongoDB Cloud - they offer 512MB of storage for free. Currently we are using (0.046GB), though we migrated but that's what it costs. Free ! 

2. To store images we use Scaleway object storage, there are more cheaper options but SCW offers 75GB free, cheap bandwidth & storage cost, no API rate limits or charges. To reduce bill we proxied object store through Cloudflare (~50-60% reduction in bandwidth). 

Currently, we are storing approximately 233GB of user uploaded images, that costs us €1.33 (this is as per our last bill) 

3. Static assets like App images, Javascripts, CSS etc, all were served through static.blinkstore.in (Cloudflare Page - Free ! ). We changed the server later but it's still same idea. 

There are more technical reasons to host assets in subdomain. I will not cover them here but it made page loads significantly faster.

4. We used self-hosted thumbor like service for resizing images, all proxied through Cloudflare, once images are resized no load on our server. It's cached through CF ! 
On-demand resize reduces cost significantly - no storage cost & no inactive store cost which means we don't need to cleanup, moreover we can change images quality as needed. 

5. For backend, we have node service which uses approximately 160MB Memory and SSR uses 50MB (custom Vue SSR Server implementation with LRU Cache).

In nutshell for Image Resizing & Backend , we are using approximately 1GB, for image resizing and Backend. ~approximately 5$ or free if you use free tiers. 

6. We use Cloudflare for caching everything, 60% or our traffic is cached ! . 

We run 3x instances of node+ssr and it can scale on demand, and  that's what it costs ~5$ !  


While Rajat Dangi and Mofid Ansari are working to scale Blinkstore, this raises a question,  Is infrastructure scalable ? Yes it is.

We have deployed things in a way that Blinkstore can scale to millions of users in few commands, that's where magic of orchestration is. I can cover it in next post if needed. 

PS: Scaleway and Cloudflare are few very generous companies check their offerings.

 #architecture #infrastructure #cloud

text.text:
If you are looking for a job change or looking to start your career with a team of tech enthusiasts, TIKAJ would be happy to review your resume and if it 'raises the bar', we would like to interview you for SDE I and SDE 2 roles. :)

These roles will be a fit if, you:
1. Are passionate about architecting and developing scalable and impactful products.
2. Wish to handle the development cycle independently and would like to mentor fellow developers.

TIKAJ prioritizes engineering excellence, focuses on up-skilling, and lets you take on challenges that help you grow along with the team.

If you're interested to explore our culture and work, apply through the openings below or send your resume to hr@tikaj.com and we can talk about the next steps!

https://lnkd.in/dXbFVcFq
https://lnkd.in/dmxrmPva
https://lnkd.in/dx47sZcN

P.S.: We are a fully remote team!

description.text: APU '24 | LU '19 | GPTW | Ex - TIKAJ | Ex-Sarthak Foundation
We appreciate you letting us know

text.text:
It has been almost 18 months since I have been working with TIKAJ. 

Working here made me realize how important culture can be in an organization and how important it is to make sure there is visibility and belongingness among your team members.

The place has given me enough time, space, and support to learn, explore, grow and work towards a better experience for the team here and it has given me opportunities to touch every aspect of my professional career. It has taught me how autonomy can make you feel stressed but responsible. 

Every day here I was taught important things like "The meaning of standups", "How to write better", " How culture can make things better or worse", and "Why self-improvement is important for yourself and your organization".

I still remember one fine day when I told my founder that I am scared of taking decisions and he told me these two powerful things :

1. Start taking decisions rather than informed and well calculative decisions take impulsive ones at times but make things move, we will incur the cost if something goes south.
2. Build processes and implement, make mistakes and again make changes and again implement, and the cycle of mistakes and changes will never stop. 
PERFECTION IS NOT WHAT WE ARE LOOKING FOR, CHANGES ARE SOMETHING THAT WE WANT."
These statements have changed things at work now and I will carry this for a lifetime. 

My manager has taught me what an ideal relationship between a Manager and a Subordinate should be like, the fight is never a Manager vs You, but rather a Manager with you vs the other people. She has taught me and defended/supported me during the right times and worst days, I can't thank her enough for the same and she has brought the smallest and lifelong changes! 

Lastly,
If you feel everything is going well and as you planned it, there should be a person who tells you there is still scope for improvement and that is how every day is a new day at TIKAJ.

With great power comes great responsibilities, I can see how important TIKAJ has become for me, and keeping it moving is not an option anymore!

You can't transform a workplace if you can't transform the lives of your team members! 

Cheers to the people helping us in making the start-up a great success.

#tikaj #culture #startup #belonging

text.text:
(Engineering#1) So recently we have been hitting 200+ requests per minute (API requests), which means, at peak some 100+ users are using Blinkstore concurrently every minute. 

It's not a huge number but it's huge given we are spending ~5$ per month on infrastructure. It's lot less than even our competition's monthly plan. 

When we started Blinkstore we never thought it will scale to these numbers so quickly but we spent lot more time optimising to not spend money in infrastructure. 

This is a mistake that I have seen in past, companies with good enough money don't spend time in optimising their tech infrastructure or even teams don't enjoy optimising anything as it's not valued by business. Eventually they end up paying huge bills, infrastructure needs a new server always, and it harms the environment. 

We are committed to keeping Blinkstore free forever and this is one of the crucial step to keeping it free forever. 

Even when we received good credits from Microsoft, we could have migrated to larger servers but It just felt unnecessary to migrate. 

Moreover, We ran benchmarks we can handle 10x more traffic with our current infrastructure. 


Please comment if you are interested in knowing what stack we used and how we lowered the cost. We can spend some effort in explaining that. 


#infrastructure #techstack #devops #startup

SDE Intern @InfoEdge (Naukri.com)
Helping enterprises in discovering and defending attack surface

text.text:
Super excited to share that Quickboarding, is finally out of stealth mode! 🎉✨

I am grateful to my team members Deeksha Gupta, Mansoor Ahmad, Himanshu sanecha and my Co-Creator Madhurendra Sachan for believing and supporting since the beginning of Quickboarding's journey. 🙏😇

We want to change people's perception about digital onboarding, which is currently limited to collecting data and documents and running automated KYCs. Instead, we want digital onboarding to be more like a real-life interaction experience, where you don't just collect data but also learn about your customer based on the insights to provide the best possible experience. 🤖

And that is why we started building Quickboarding. 

Quickboarding stands out from the competition because it is the only comprehensive customer onboarding platform that lets you build the onboarding process the way you want and not the way your software dictates. 🤩

We're also looking for early-adopters who are passionate about providing personalized and customer centric onboarding experience to their customers. 🙌

For time being we have limited our early adopters to just Fintechs & NBFCs. If you think our product can help someone you know, please leave a comment or tag them. 

Cheers!!  🚀
-Abhishek

#earlyaccess #digitalonboarding #startup #onboarding #nocode #saas
